study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate L-Tyrosine (LT) as a potential bio-therapeutic agent derived from endophytic fungi, focusing on its antibacterial, anti-biofilm, and safety properties.
results_summary: LT demonstrated strong antibacterial and anti-biofilm activities against multidrug-resistant bacteria, with MIC values ranging from 6 to 20 µg/ml. It also showed hemocompatibility and no cytotoxicity, supporting its potential as a therapeutic agent.
population_specificity: Multidrug-resistant Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether laser-assisted drug delivery (LADD) of synthetic α-MSH combined with L-Tyrosine could increase pigmentation and melanogenesis gene expression in hypopigmented hypertrophic scars (HTS).
results_summary: The study found that LADD of synthetic α-MSH + L-Tyrosine increased hyperpigmentation area and melanogenesis gene expression (TYR, TYRP1, DCT) in hypopigmented HTS over four weeks. L-Tyrosine alone also increased melanogenesis gene expression, though less consistently than the combination treatment.
population_specificity: Red Duroc pigs with induced hypertrophic scars (HTS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (topical solution concentration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of FET PET (using O-(2-[18F]fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine) in clinical decision-making for brain tumor diagnosis and treatment, including its indications and referring physicians' perceptions.
results_summary: The study found that FET PET was highly rated by physicians for diagnosing recurrent glioma (95%) and recurrent brain metastases (68%), and was considered important for treatment planning and monitoring. The demand for FET PET increased over time, and physicians unanimously supported its approval for routine use.
population_specificity: Patients with suspected or confirmed brain tumors (gliomas, brain metastases, or unclear brain lesions) referred for FET PET imaging.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a highly sensitive electrochemical sensor (MoS2@BiVO4) for detecting 3-nitro-l-tyrosine (NO2-Tyr), a biomarker of nitrosative stress, in biological samples.
results_summary: The MoS2@BiVO4 sensor demonstrated excellent electrochemical performance, with low resistance charge transfer (159.13 Ω·cm2), a wide response range (0.001-526.3 μM), and high selectivity (against 10 interfering compounds). It successfully detected NO2-Tyr in water, urine, and saliva samples with high recovery rates (±98.94-99.98%).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and biological media samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of various 18F-FET parameters in distinguishing true progression from treatment-related changes in brain tumours.
results_summary: The study found that static parameters (TBRmax and TBRmean) showed high sensitivity (82%) in differentiating true progression from TRC, while combining static and kinetic parameters improved diagnostic performance (90% sensitivity).
population_specificity: Patients with brain tumours post-therapy (including recurrent and metastatic brain tumours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the complexation of L-tyrosine with metal ions and its influence on chlorination, including the formation of disinfection byproducts (DBPs).
results_summary: L-tyrosine formed complexes with metal ions, altering chlorination kinetics and DBP formation, reducing trihalomethane production by 21.5% but increasing haloacetic acids by 26.9%. Alkaline conditions and UV/chlorine disinfection enhanced DBP generation.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study, no human participants)
interactions: Metal ions (Ca2+, Fe3+, Mn2+) and chlorine disinfection

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how nitisinone (NTBC) and its metabolites influence L-tyrosine (L-TYR) catabolism in Raphanus sativus var. longipinnatus.
results_summary: NTBC and its metabolites differentially affected L-TYR catabolism, with significant changes in epinephrine and normetanephrine levels—NTBC increased them (+42%), while two metabolites decreased them (-39% and -55%). Cyclohexane-1,3-dione had no effect on these neurotransmitters.
population_specificity: Raphanus sativus var. longipinnatus (a plant model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-arbovirus activity of ten di-halogenated compounds derived from L-tyrosine against dengue, Zika, and chikungunya viruses.
results_summary: Two compounds (TDC-2M-ME and TDB-2M-ME) inhibited both Zika and chikungunya viruses, reducing viral genome copies and infectious particles. TDB-2M-ME also demonstrated virucidal effects against Zika virus and inhibited viral protein in U937 cells.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using VERO and U937 cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the catecholamine pathway-mediated synthesis of L-DOPA from L-tyrosine in Mucuna pruriens and identify the key enzyme involved.
results_summary: The study detected L-tyrosine, tyramine, L-DOPA, and dopamine in callus cultures and plant tissues, with polyphenol oxidase (PPO) showing higher activity than tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) in metabolically active young leaves. Gene expression profiles correlated strongly with L-DOPA synthesis, supporting PPO as the candidate enzyme.
population_specificity: Mucuna pruriens plant tissues and callus cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-Tyrosine, in combination with trisodium citrate, could efficiently direct the growth of twisted gold nanorods for potential use in cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that L-Tyrosine, when used with trisodium citrate in specific concentrations, effectively directed the formation of twisted gold nanorods with a flat plasmon band extending into the NIR-III range, suitable for photothermal and photodynamic therapy applications. The growth mechanism was accurately modeled using a Diffusion Limited Aggregation numerical scheme.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the production of synthetic allomelanin from L-tyrosine and L-lysine using engineered E. coli strains, and to evaluate its potential applications in fabric dyeing.
results_summary: The study found that melanin produced from L-tyrosine had comparable ABTS radical scavenging capacity to caffeic acid-based melanin. Engineered E. coli strains successfully facilitated the production of melanin and C5-diamine from L-tyrosine and L-lysine, with potential improvements in dyeing fastness when treated with laccase enzyme.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro and microbial study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of an ultra-short course of AIT with an L-tyrosine-adsorbed olive pollen extract in patients with allergic asthma.
results_summary: The study found that AIT with Pollinex Quattro® reduced unscheduled healthcare visits and emergency room admissions, decreased asthma medication use, and improved rhinitis symptoms, with mild adverse reactions reported in a minority of patients.
population_specificity: Patients with allergic asthma, with or without allergic rhinitis, sensitized to olive pollen in Spain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study mentions Pollinex Quattro® 100% olive pollen or 50% olive/50% grass pollen, but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic potential of [18F]FET PET in brain tumor diagnostics, including delineation, therapy planning, and differentiation between tumor recurrence and treatment-related changes.
results_summary: [18F]FET PET provides high contrast between tumor tissue and benign alterations, with low accumulation in healthy brain tissue and benign lesions. It has largely replaced short-lived amino acid tracers like [11C]MET in Western Europe due to logistical advantages and strong clinical results.
population_specificity: Patients with brain tumors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of L-Tyrosine polyurethane (LTU) nanoparticles as a biocompatible and biodegradable gene carrier for effective gene therapy with minimal toxicity and high transfection efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that LTU nanoparticles exhibited excellent cellular uptake, high transfection efficiency, and sustained gene release, with minimal cytotoxicity in both normal (LX2) and cancer (HepG2, MCF7) cell lines. The optimal pDNA-LPEI concentration ratio of 1:10 facilitated effective gene encapsulation and delivery.
population_specificity: In vitro study using LX2 (normal cells), HepG2, and MCF7 (cancer cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the prognostic value of dynamic FET PET (using L-Tyrosine) in newly diagnosed, histomolecularly classified astrocytic gliomas of WHO grades III or IV.
results_summary: The study found that dynamic FET PET parameters, particularly time-to-peak (TTP), were highly prognostic for longer progression-free and overall survival in IDH-wildtype glioma patients. Other static FET PET parameters (TBRmax, TBRmean, MTV) showed lower but still significant prognostic value for overall survival.
population_specificity: Patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma (GBM) and anaplastic astrocytoma (AA) (n=60, 45 GBM and 15 AA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of 18F-FET PET in detecting residual tumor tissue and reactive changes after glioma resection.
results_summary: The study found that 18F-FET PET effectively identified residual tumor tissue post-resection, with a flare phenomenon observed in 26% of patients. Reactive changes at the resection cavity were mild, but the flare phenomenon warrants further investigation.
population_specificity: 43 patients with cerebral gliomas (9 low-grade, 34 high-grade; 9 primary tumors, 34 recurrent tumors).
effective_dosage: Not specified (PET scans performed 20-40 min after injection).
study_duration: Preoperative (median 23 days before surgery) and postoperative (median 14 days after surgery) PET scans.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neurological effects of chronic L-tyrosine administration and the potential neuroprotective role of Omega-3 fatty acids in a rodent model of Tyrosinemia type II.
results_summary: Chronic L-tyrosine administration increased pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokines in brain structures, particularly the cerebral cortex and striatum. Omega-3 supplementation attenuated these inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Young rats (infant rodent model of Tyrosinemia type II).
interactions: Omega-3 fatty acids (n-3 PUFA) supplementation was noted to attenuate L-tyrosine-induced inflammation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of L-tyrosine supplementation, alone and combined with treadmill exercise, on reducing epileptiform activity in rats.
results_summary: L-tyrosine supplementation significantly decreased spike frequency in epileptiform activity compared to the control group, though no significant differences were observed in spike amplitude or latency. The combination of L-tyrosine and exercise also showed similar efficacy in reducing seizure activity.
population_specificity: Male albino Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg/day, administered via oral gavage (2.5 mL solution)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effects of synthesized L-benzyl tyrosine thiol carboxylic acid analogues against metallo-β-lactamase (IMP-1) to address antibiotic resistance.
results_summary: The synthesized molecules (2a-2k) showed potent inhibitory effects against IMP-1 with Kic values ranging from 1.04-4.77 µM, though they were less potent than the candidate inhibitor.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of 18F-FET PET imaging for monitoring outcomes following dendritic cell (DC) vaccination therapy in glioblastoma patients, not specifically L-Tyrosine.
results_summary: The study found that 18F-FET PET imaging provided additional diagnostic value compared to MRI in distinguishing tumor progression from treatment-related changes in glioblastoma patients receiving DC vaccination. Three out of five patients showed congruent results, while PET identified treatment-related changes in cases where MRI suggested tumor progression.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma patients (1 female, 4 males; mean age 44 ± 14 years) who received DC vaccination therapy.
study_duration: Vaccination was performed five times, either weekly during treatment or after tumor recurrence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cost-effectiveness of [18F] fluoroethyl-L-tyrosine ([18F] FET) PET scans in predicting treatment responses for glioblastoma patients undergoing temozolomide maintenance therapy.
results_summary: The study found that [18F] FET PET scans identified 57.14% more non-responders compared to conventional MRI, with incremental cost-effectiveness ratios of 1,365.86 and 1,357.38 euros per identified non-responder for overall and progression-free survival, respectively. The sensitivity analyses confirmed the robustness of these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with glioblastoma (WHO grade IV tumors) post-surgery and before temozolomide maintenance treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on diagnostic imaging, not supplementation).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up phase involved two PET scans per patient).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential benefits of L-Tyrosine supplementation in reducing sialorrhea and improving muscle strength in a newborn with nemaline myopathy.
results_summary: The study found that L-Tyrosine treatment led to a remarkable decrease in sialorrhea and improvement in spontaneous movements in the newborn patient. The results suggest a possible therapeutic benefit, though the study is limited to a single case.
population_specificity: A newborn with severe respiratory failure and generalized muscle weakness diagnosed with nemaline myopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic performance of F-FET PET in differentiating late pseudoprogression from true tumor recurrence in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) patients.
results_summary: F-FET PET reliably distinguished pseudoprogression from true tumor progression, with high diagnostic accuracy (AUC 0.80-0.88). Different analytical approaches showed minor performance differences, with methods focusing on highest uptake voxels performing slightly better.
population_specificity: 36 patients with histopathologically confirmed GBM and suspected recurrence/progression more than 12 weeks post-irradiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical significance of photopenic defects in FET-negative gliomas and their association with tumor grade and progression-free survival.
results_summary: The study found that photopenic gliomas had significantly decreased FET uptake compared to healthy brain tissue and gliomas with indifferent uptake, and these tumors were associated with higher-grade gliomas and unfavorable progression-free survival.
population_specificity: Glioma patients with negative FET PET scans prior to neuropathological confirmation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prognostic value of [18F]FET-PET/CT imaging in newly diagnosed grade II or III gliomas according to the 2016 WHO classification.
results_summary: The study found that [18F]FET uptake was higher in grade III gliomas and correlated with shorter progression-free survival (PFS). PET-positive gliomas had worse prognoses compared to PET-negative lesions, suggesting [18F]FET-PET/CT is useful for non-invasive tumor assessment.
population_specificity: 35 treatment-naive patients (mean age 48 ± 17 years) with histologically proven WHO grade II or III gliomas.
effective_dosage: Not specified (static PET/CT imaging performed 20 min after intravenous [18F]FET injection).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of n-3 PUFA against alterations caused by chronic L-tyrosine administration on energetic metabolism and oxidative stress in the brains of developing rats.
results_summary: Chronic L-tyrosine administration disrupted enzyme activities related to energy metabolism and increased oxidative stress in multiple brain regions. n-3 PUFA supplementation prevented most of these alterations and reduced oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Developing rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic utility and uptake mechanisms of O-(2-[18F]fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine (FET) in cerebral gliomas and brain metastases.
results_summary: FET PET provides important diagnostic information for delineating cerebral gliomas, differentiating tumor recurrence from treatment-related changes, and monitoring treatment. Experimental studies have clarified FET uptake specificity for tumor tissue and the impact of treatment-related alterations on tracer uptake.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral gliomas and brain metastases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of dual-time point FET PET/CT in detecting SVZ involvement and predicting survival outcomes in glioblastoma patients.
results_summary: The study found that FET PET-based tumor volumes were associated with worse prognosis, and SVZ infiltration detected by FET PET was linked to poor survival, though its independent prognostic value was not confirmed. Larger tumor volumes and worse KPS were also associated with shorter survival.
population_specificity: 35 patients with glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) before starting radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative FET-PET imaging using O-(2-18Ffluoroethyl)-l-tyrosine could predict the location of glioblastoma recurrence more effectively than MRI alone.
results_summary: FET-PET predicted tumor recurrence location in 78% of cases (25/32), outperforming MRI (42%). Tumor recurrence correlated with elevated TTB ratios on FET-PET in 79% of cases, suggesting higher sensitivity than MRI.
population_specificity: 32 consecutive patients with glioblastoma and available perioperative/follow-up imaging data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the uptake of 2-18F-fluoroethyl-l-tyrosine (18F-FET) and l-[methyl-3H]-methionine (3H-MET) in residual tumor after surgery and assess false-positive uptake in treatment-related changes.
results_summary: The study found that surgery induced significant treatment-related uptake of 18F-FET and 3H-MET near the resection cavity in the first week after surgery, likely due to reactive astrogliosis. Tracer uptake in residual or recurrent tumor tissue exceeded treatment-related uptake, but the latter was comparable to human gliomas, suggesting amino acid PET may be more reliable after a 14-day interval.
population_specificity: Rats with implanted F98 or GS-9L gliomas.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tracer uptake quantified by lesion-to-brain ratios).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro and in vivo antidiabetic effects of synthesized N-Boc-L-tyrosine-based analogues, focusing on their polypharmacological activity.
results_summary: Compounds 1 and 3 showed strong PTP-1B inhibition, increased mRNA expression of PPARγ, GLUT-4, PPARα, and FATP-1, and effectively reduced blood glucose in hyperglycemic murine models.
population_specificity: Murine model of hyperglycemia (non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of FET PET and MRI in identifying viable tumor tissue in a pretreated glioblastoma patient, using postmortem histology as the gold standard.
results_summary: FET PET accurately identified areas of dense tumor infiltration in the glioblastoma patient, correlating well with histology, while areas of reactive astrogliosis showed only moderate FET uptake. The study demonstrated FET PET's superiority over MRI in distinguishing tumor progression from treatment-related changes.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old patient with glioblastoma who had undergone partial tumor resection and chemoradiation.
study_duration: FET PET and MRI were performed 3 days before death; autopsy was conducted 48 hours postmortem.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of dexamethasone therapy on [18F]FET (a derivative of L-Tyrosine) uptake in the normal brain and its effect on tumor-to-brain ratios in brain tumor patients.
results_summary: Dexamethasone treatment increased [18F]FET uptake in the normal brain, with higher uptake observed in women than men. No significant differences were found in tumor-to-brain ratios, though a case showed decreased ratios and biological tumor volume after dexamethasone.
population_specificity: 160 brain tumor patients (80 dexamethasone-treated, 80 untreated; balanced by gender).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic performance of O-(2-18F-fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine (18F-FET) PET and perfusion-weighted MRI (PWI) for detecting progressive or recurrent glioma.
results_summary: 18F-FET PET showed significantly higher sensitivity (76%) than PWI (52%) for detecting abnormalities in pretreated gliomas. The maximum tumor-to-brain ratio of 18F-FET PET was the best discriminator between treatment-related changes and progressive/recurrent gliomas (AUC 0.78, sensitivity 80%, specificity 86%).
population_specificity: 32 patients with pretreated gliomas (25 progressive/recurrent tumors, 7 treatment-related changes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the diagnostic accuracy of FET PET scanning in detecting malignant transformation of low-grade gliomas (LGGs) and its relationship with MRI and molecular biomarkers.
results_summary: The study found that FET PET alone had limited value in distinguishing transformed from nontransformed LGGs, though combining FET parameters (TBRmax > 1.6 and TAC with a plateau/decreasing pattern) improved differentiation in certain subgroups. FET PET was not adequate to replace histological confirmation but could provide useful information on tumor location and biology.
population_specificity: Patients with previously treated, histologically verified low-grade gliomas (LGGs) showing clinical/MRI signs of progression (n=42).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chronic L-tyrosine administration on cholinergic system activity (ChAT and AChE) in rat brains and assess whether antioxidant treatment could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: Chronic L-tyrosine administration decreased ChAT activity in the cerebral cortex and increased AChE activity in the hippocampus, striatum, and cerebral cortex. Antioxidant treatment partially prevented these changes but did not fully restore AChE activity in the cerebral cortex.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utility of FET-PET (using 18F-fluoroethyl-l-tyrosine) in improving radiation therapy target volume delineation for patients with high-grade glioma who cannot undergo MRI.
results_summary: FET-PET identified disease outside CT-defined targets in two patients and suggested a potential geographical miss in one patient, indicating improved delineation accuracy compared to CT-alone. The conformity index was 0.78, with a mean 31.6% increase in target volume when using FET-PET.
population_specificity: Patients with high-grade glioma and contraindications to MRI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic utility of F-18 labelled O-(2-[18F]fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine (FET) in improving the differentiation and management of cerebral gliomas and brain metastases.
results_summary: FET PET demonstrated high tumour-to-background contrast, stability, and specific tracer kinetics, aiding in biopsy site definition, therapy planning, treatment monitoring, and distinguishing tumour recurrence from treatment-related changes. The RANO working group endorsed its clinical use.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral gliomas and brain metastases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ortho-phospho-L-tyrosine (pTyr) prevents radiotherapy-induced side effects and affects tumour control in retinoblastoma mouse models.
results_summary: pTyr reduced radiotherapy-induced side effects (fur greying, retinal degeneration) in Rb+/- mice but decreased tumour control in the xenograft model. In vitro, pTyr modulated p53 activity but did not radioprotect Y79 cells.
population_specificity: B6;129-Rb1tm3Tyj/J (Rb+/-) mice and Y79-Rb cell-xenografted nude mice.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight, 16 hours prior to each irradiation (15 fractions over 3 weeks).
study_duration: 3 weeks (with follow-up evaluations up to 9 months post-RT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether N-stearoyl-L-tyrosine (Nstyr) could reverse oxidative stress-induced cellular senescence and apoptosis in HEK293/Tau cells via CB2 receptor activation.
results_summary: Nstyr inhibited oxidative stress-induced cellular senescence and apoptosis in HEK293/Tau cells, an effect mediated by CB2 receptor activation, as confirmed by antagonist and siRNA experiments.
population_specificity: HEK293 cells transfected with Tau 411 plasmid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of FET PET combined with MRI versus MRI alone for diagnosing recurrent brain metastases.
results_summary: FET PET combined with MRI increased correct diagnosis rates by 42% compared to MRI alone, with incremental cost-effectiveness ratios of €2821–€4014 per correct diagnosis, suggesting potential cost-effectiveness and reduced overtreatment.
population_specificity: Patients with suspected recurrent brain metastases after radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether antioxidants (NAC and DFX) could mitigate the negative effects of chronic L-Tyrosine administration on energy metabolism enzymes in the brain.
results_summary: Chronic L-Tyrosine administration reduced citrate synthase and succinate dehydrogenase activities in multiple brain regions, while antioxidants prevented some of these effects. However, antioxidants did not prevent the inhibition of creatine kinase activity in the striatum.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate L-Tyrosine-based poly(ester-urethane)s as enzyme-responsive drug delivery vehicles for cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that L-Tyrosine nanoparticles effectively encapsulated and delivered anticancer drugs (doxorubicin and camptothecin), showing high cellular uptake and targeted drug release with minimal toxicity to normal cells. The nanoparticles demonstrated superior drug delivery compared to free drugs.
population_specificity: Cervical cancer (HeLa) cells and normal WT-MEFs cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic utility of 18F-FET PET in detecting and monitoring brainstem and spinal cord gliomas, particularly when MRI results were inconclusive.
results_summary: The study found that 18F-FET PET provided valuable diagnostic information, especially in high-grade gliomas and some low-grade gliomas, and correctly identified tumor progression in 82% of cases when combined with kinetic parameters.
population_specificity: 29 patients with brainstem or spinal cord gliomas (15 newly diagnosed, 14 follow-up).
effective_dosage: Not specified (18F-FET PET scans performed, dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (follow-up scans varied by patient).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether 18F-FET uptake in glioblastomas is independent of BBB permeability and reliably reflects tumor viability during antiangiogenic therapy with bevacizumab.
results_summary: The study found that 18F-FET uptake in glioblastomas remained largely unaffected by changes in BBB permeability induced by bevacizumab, suggesting it more reliably indicates tumor viability than contrast-enhanced MRI. Both short-term and long-term bevacizumab therapy reduced BBB permeability, but 18F-FET uptake ratios and slopes showed no significant differences.
population_specificity: Immunodeficient RNU rats with implanted human U87 glioblastoma cells.
effective_dosage: Single high dose (45 mg/kg) or two lower doses (10 mg/kg each) of bevacizumab.
study_duration: Short-term (2 days before PET) and long-term (9 and 2 days before PET) effects were evaluated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential antidepressant effects of L-tyrosine-loaded nanoparticles in acute and chronic mild stress models of depression in rats.
results_summary: L-tyrosine-loaded nanoparticles (10 mg/kg) significantly reduced immobility time in the forced swim test, restored locomotor activity, and increased sucrose consumption, comparable to fluoxetine. The effects were likely due to restored cerebral noradrenaline levels.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to acute and chronic mild stress models of depression.
effective_dosage: 5 or 10 mg/kg of L-tyrosine-loaded nanoparticles, 10 mg/kg of L-tyrosine solution, and 10 mg/kg of fluoxetine, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether the uptake of O-(2-18F-fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine (18F-FET) in brain tumors is influenced by blood-brain barrier (BBB) permeability, using rat glioma and human xenograft models.
results_summary: Dexamethasone (Dex) treatment significantly reduced BBB permeability but did not notably alter 18F-FET uptake, suggesting that 18F-FET uptake in gliomas is largely independent of BBB permeability. Ultrastructural analysis confirmed Dex reduced endothelial cell gaps in tumor blood vessels.
population_specificity: Fischer or RNU rats with implanted F98 glioma, 9L gliosarcoma, or human U87 glioblastoma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of epileptic seizures on brain amino acid metabolism using 18F-FET PET imaging and to understand the underlying pathophysiology.
results_summary: The study found that seizure activity, particularly status epilepticus, increased cerebral amino acid transport, leading to a distinct gyral 18F-FET uptake pattern. This uptake was reversible and could mimic brain tumor progression, indicating a potential pitfall in 18F-FET PET imaging.
population_specificity: Ten patients with serial seizures or status epilepticus, including those with gliomas (WHO grade II-IV) and nonneoplastic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hybrid F-FET PET/MRI could distinguish glioma recurrence from radiation necrosis using multiple structural and functional parameters.
results_summary: The study found that FET uptake combined with Cho/Cr ratio and normalized rCBVmean was highly accurate (up to 97%) in differentiating glioma recurrence from radiation necrosis, with TBRmax and Cho/Cr ratio being particularly effective.
population_specificity: 26 patients (5 female, 21 male; mean age 51.58 ± 15.97 years) with contrast-enhancing brain lesions post-surgery and radiation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biochemical transformation of L-tyrosine to L-DOPA using Aspergillus niger PA2 and assess its potential for large-scale L-DOPA production.
results_summary: The study found that Aspergillus niger PA2 effectively converted L-tyrosine to L-DOPA, producing 2.44 mg/mL of L-DOPA when supplemented with 5 mg/mL of L-tyrosine. Optimal production occurred at pH 6.0, and the product was confirmed as L-DOPA through multiple analytical methods.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using Aspergillus niger PA2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the reproducibility of (18)F-FET uptake kinetics in rat gliomas and the influence of dexamethasone therapy on these measurements.
results_summary: The study found high longitudinal stability in tumor-to-brain ratios (TBR) of (18)F-FET uptake, with an intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) of 0.84 after correcting for tumor growth. Dexamethasone treatment caused a significant decrease in TBR (-8.2%) but did not affect the slope of the time-activity curves.
population_specificity: Fischer rats with implanted F98 glioma or 9L gliosarcoma cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dynamic PET after injection of (18)F-FET).
study_duration: 2 days between baseline and follow-up scans.
interactions: Dexamethasone was noted to decrease TBR but did not affect tracer kinetics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the application of L-Tyrosine-based dipeptides as affinity ligands for purifying supercoiled plasmid DNA (pDNA) in gene therapy and vaccine development.
results_summary: The study found that L-Tyrosine-based dipeptides, particularly L-Tyrosine-L-Arginine, showed high affinity for supercoiled pDNA, enabling effective purification. Chromatographic experiments demonstrated successful separation of plasmid samples using L-Tyrosine Sepharose, with adjustments in gradient conditions improving results.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether O-(2-[(18)F]fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine (18F-FET) PET could effectively differentiate between late pseudoprogression (PsP) and true tumor progression in glioblastoma patients.
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET-PET effectively distinguished true tumor progression from late PsP, with significantly higher tumor/brain ratios (TBRmax and TBRmean) and shorter time-to-peak (TTP) in true progression cases. ROC analysis identified a TBRmax cutoff of 1.9 with high sensitivity (84%) and specificity (86%).
population_specificity: 26 glioblastoma patients presenting with increasing contrast-enhancing lesions later than 3 months after radiochemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of static and dynamic (18)F-FET PET parameters in detecting tumor progression or recurrence in glioma patients compared to conventional MRI.
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET PET parameters (mean tumor/brain ratio ≥2.0 or time to peak <45 min) achieved higher diagnostic accuracy (93%) than conventional MRI (85%) in identifying tumor progression or recurrence, with high sensitivity (93%) and specificity (100%).
population_specificity: 124 glioma patients (WHO grade II, III, and IV) with clinical signs or MRI findings suggestive of tumor progression or recurrence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop strategies for bonding L-Tyrosine and poly-L-tyrosine to graphene oxide nanoribbons (GONRs) for potential biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study successfully demonstrated covalent attachment of L-Tyrosine to GONRs via amidation and esterification, and characterized the biofunctionalized nanomaterials using various spectroscopic and analytical techniques. Potential applications of these hybrid nanomaterials in biomedicine were proposed.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a QSAR model to screen new MMP-2 inhibitors based on the L-hydroxy tyrosine scaffold and validate their binding potential through docking studies.
results_summary: The study successfully generated QSAR models (MLR and GA-PLS) with high predictive accuracy (Q² LOO > 0.900) and identified key molecular features influencing MMP-2 inhibition, such as lipophilic interactions and hydrogen bonding. Docking studies confirmed the importance of specific functional groups and substituents in ligand-receptor interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel method for selectively extracting and screening L-Tyrosine as a potential lung cancer biomarker in human plasma samples.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the modified molecularly imprinted sol-gel polysulfone membrane (MSM) method was highly selective, repeatable, and efficient for extracting L-Tyrosine, with a recovery rate of 80%-85% and a linear range of 0.34-2000 nmol L(-1). The method showed high precision and accuracy, with coefficients of determination ≥0.998.
population_specificity: Human plasma samples (specific population not detailed beyond this).
effective_dosage: Not specified (method focused on extraction, not administration).
study_duration: Not specified (methodological study, not an intervention trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the diagnostic utility of O-(2-(18)F-fluoroethyl)-l-tyrosine ((18)F-FET) PET imaging in detecting incidental pituitary disease and differentiating cerebral metastases/recurrence.
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET PET imaging provided valuable insights into pituitary disease pathogenesis and demonstrated superior differentiation of cerebral metastases/recurrence compared to MR imaging and (18)F-FDG PET. The case represented a rare finding on (18)F-FET PET.
population_specificity: Patients with previous surgical and radiation therapy for cerebral metastases/recurrence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical value of O-(2-(18)F-fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine ((18)F-FET) PET in differentiating pseudoprogression (PsP) from early tumour progression (EP) in glioblastoma patients post-radiochemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET uptake was significantly lower in PsP patients compared to EP patients, with optimal TBRmax cut-off of 2.3 (100% sensitivity, 91% specificity). A TBRmax <2.3 predicted longer overall survival (23 vs. 12 months).
population_specificity: 22 glioblastoma patients with new or increased contrast-enhancing lesions within 12 weeks post-radiochemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pharmacologic inhibition of L-Tyrosine degradation could restore dopamine synthesis in a murine model of PKU by counteracting Phe-mediated inhibition of tyrosine hydroxylase activity.
results_summary: The study found that oral nitisinone (NTBC) increased blood and brain Tyr levels, reduced Phe levels, and enhanced dopamine synthesis in PKU mice, suggesting Phe-mediated TH inhibition as the primary mechanism of impaired dopamine synthesis.
population_specificity: Murine model of phenylketonuria (PKU)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an affinity chromatographic strategy using an O-phospho-l-tyrosine matrix to purify pre-miR-29 for potential gene therapy applications in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study achieved 52% purity and 71% recovery yield of pre-miR-29 using a decreasing ammonium sulfate gradient in Tris buffer at pH 8 and 16°C, demonstrating the O-phospho-l-tyrosine matrix's selectivity and the effectiveness of Box-Behnken design for optimization.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the production of L-DOPA using Yarrowia lipolytica-NCIM 3450 by adjusting physical and nutritional parameters, including L-Tyrosine.
results_summary: The study achieved a 3.594-fold increase in L-DOPA yield, with optimized conditions (pH 6.1, 1.491 g/L L-Tyrosine) producing 1.273 g/L L-DOPA, closely matching the predicted yield. The model was statistically significant (F value 19.55, R² 0.9514).
population_specificity: Yarrowia lipolytica-NCIM 3450 (microbial culture)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of FET-PET uptake intensity in WHO grade II-IV gliomas, focusing on tumor-related mortality and progression-free survival.
results_summary: Higher SUVmax (≥2.6) in FET-PET was significantly associated with worse tumor-related mortality and shorter progression-free survival, independent of tumor volume or TBR. WHO tumor grade and SUVmax were key predictors of outcomes.
population_specificity: 28 patients with WHO grade II-IV gliomas referred for radiation therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (FET-PET tracer dose not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the production of l-DOPA from l-tyrosine using Yarrowia lipolytica-NCIM 3472 biomass and assess the effectiveness of response surface methodology (RSM) in enhancing yield.
results_summary: The study found that optimized process parameters (pH 7.31, temperature 42.9°C, 2.31 g/l cell mass, and 1.488 g/l l-tyrosine) resulted in a 4.609-fold increase in l-DOPA production, with a maximum yield of 4.091 g/l. The model was statistically significant, and l-DOPA production was confirmed by HPTLC and HPLC analysis.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using Yarrowia lipolytica-NCIM 3472 biomass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if O-(2-(18)F-fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine ((18)F-FET) PET could noninvasively detect malignant progression in patients with low-grade glioma (LGG).
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET PET parameters (TBRmax, TTP, and time-activity curve patterns) significantly changed in patients with malignant progression, providing higher diagnostic accuracy than conventional MR imaging. The combined analysis of these parameters yielded an 81% accuracy for detecting progression.
population_specificity: 27 patients with histologically proven low-grade glioma (WHO grade II).
study_duration: Longitudinal study with two PET scans per patient, timing based on clinical suspicion of progression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether acute administration of L-Tyrosine induces oxidative stress in specific brain regions of rats, potentially contributing to neurological dysfunction in hypertyrosinemia.
results_summary: Acute L-Tyrosine administration increased oxidative stress markers (thiobarbituric acid-reactive species and protein carbonyl content) in the hippocampus, cerebellum, and striatum, while reducing superoxide dismutase activity and increasing catalase activity in some regions.
population_specificity: 30-day-old rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vivo transfection capabilities and immunogenicity of L-Tyrosine polyphosphate (LTP) nanoparticles as a nonviral gene vector.
results_summary: The study found successful in vivo transfection in rodent uterine tissue after nine days, confirmed by X-gal staining, immunohistochemistry, and RT-PCR. No significant activation of the innate immune system was observed, indicating low immunogenicity.
population_specificity: Rodent (mouse model) uterine tissue.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness and diagnostic effectiveness of adding (18)F-FET PET to structural MR imaging for managing BEV/IR treatment in recurrent high-grade glioma patients.
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET PET improved diagnostic accuracy (number needed to diagnose = 2.4) and was cost-effective (incremental cost-effectiveness ratio of €5,725–€8,145 per correct diagnosis). The integration of PET helped avoid overtreatment and unnecessary side effects.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent high-grade glioma

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 18F-FET-PET imaging using L-Tyrosine could improve the diagnosis of tumor progression in glioblastoma patients undergoing bevacizumab treatment compared to standard MRI-based RANO criteria.
results_summary: The study found that 18F-FET-PET imaging suggested earlier detection of tumor progression in a glioblastoma patient compared to MRI changes based on RANO criteria, indicating potential diagnostic utility.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma patient receiving bevacizumab treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether reactive astrogliosis near untreated and irradiated rat gliomas leads to significant uptake of (18)F-FET, potentially affecting tumor imaging accuracy.
results_summary: The study found that reactive astrogliosis near gliomas showed only slight (18)F-FET uptake, generally not affecting tumor size estimation, except in two cases with high-dose irradiation (150 Gy) where uptake in astrogliosis led to overestimation. (18)F-FET uptake in tumors was congruent with histological tumor extent in most cases.
population_specificity: Fisher CDF rats with implanted F98-glioma cells.
effective_dosage: Not specified for L-Tyrosine; irradiation doses varied (2/50 Gy, 3/75 Gy, 6/100 Gy, 6/150 Gy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare MRI and [(18)F]fluoroethyl-L-tyrosine PET imaging findings in a patient with bevacizumab treatment failure to assess tumor response.
results_summary: The study found discrepant imaging results between MRI and [(18)F]fluoroethyl-L-tyrosine PET in a patient with bevacizumab treatment failure, suggesting potential limitations of MRI criteria for tumor response assessment.
population_specificity: A single patient with bevacizumab treatment failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical applications of (18)F-FET PET, an L-Tyrosine-based tracer, for diagnosing and monitoring low-grade gliomas (LGG).
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET PET provides valuable metabolic information for LGG diagnosis, tumor delineation, and therapy monitoring, with logistical advantages over other tracers due to its longer half-life. It demonstrated comparable diagnostic efficacy to (11)C-methyl-L-methionine.
population_specificity: Patients with low-grade glioma (LGG).

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of (18)F-FET PET versus MRI in assessing treatment response in recurrent high-grade glioma patients undergoing antiangiogenic therapy.
results_summary: (18)F-FET PET identified metabolic responders more effectively than MRI, predicting longer progression-free and overall survival. PET also detected tumor progression earlier than MRI in some cases.
population_specificity: Ten patients with recurrent high-grade glioma (rHGG).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on imaging, not L-Tyrosine dosage).
study_duration: Median follow-up of 4.9 weeks after treatment initiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether O-(2-(18)F-fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine ((18)F-FET) PET could differentiate local recurrent brain metastasis from radiation necrosis after radiation therapy.
results_summary: The study found that (18)F-FET PET, particularly when combining tumor-to-brain ratios (TBR) and time-activity curve patterns, accurately differentiated recurrent brain metastasis from radiation necrosis with high diagnostic accuracy (up to 93%).
population_specificity: 31 patients (mean age 53 ± 11 years) with single or multiple contrast-enhancing brain lesions after radiation therapy for brain metastases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in (18)F-FET PET imaging could predict treatment response and survival in glioblastoma patients compared to MRI.
results_summary: The study found that early decreases in (18)F-FET PET tumor-to-brain ratios (TBR(max) and TBR(mean)) were highly predictive of progression-free and overall survival, while MRI gadolinium volume changes were not. A 20% decrease in TBR(max) post-treatment predicted favorable survival with 83% sensitivity.
population_specificity: 25 patients with glioblastoma post-surgery undergoing radiochemotherapy with temozolomide.
study_duration: Assessments were made early (7-10 days) and later (6-8 weeks) after radiochemotherapy completion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic value of F-18 FET PET-derived indices for differentiating low-grade from high-grade gliomas and to assess the individual probability of high-grade glioma using logistic regression.
results_summary: High-grade gliomas showed significantly higher values in early SUV, early-to-middle ratio, early-to-late ratio, Tpeak, and SoD compared to low-grade gliomas. The early-to-middle SUV ratio and Tpeak provided the highest diagnostic accuracy (94%), and logistic regression achieved 97% accuracy for high-grade diagnosis.
population_specificity: Patients with low-grade (WHO I-II) and high-grade (WHO III-IV) gliomas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize L-DOPA production using L-tyrosine as a substrate with Brevundimonas sp. SGJ and evaluate the effects of enhancers on yield.
results_summary: The study achieved a high L-DOPA yield (3.81 g l⁻¹, 95.2%) using 4 g l⁻¹ L-tyrosine under optimized conditions, with peak tyrosinase activity observed at 18 hours. The produced L-DOPA was confirmed by multiple analytical methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using bacterial biomass).
effective_dosage: 2 g l⁻¹ L-tyrosine (initial), 4 g l⁻¹ (highest yield).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare MRI and (18)F-FET PET response assessments in patients with recurrent high-grade glioma undergoing antiangiogenic treatment.
results_summary: (18)F-FET PET detected tumor progression earlier than MRI in some cases and was predictive of treatment failure, with metabolic responders showing longer survival than nonresponders. MRI and PET assessments were discordant in 36.4% of cases.
population_specificity: Patients with recurrent high-grade glioma (rHGG)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single dose of L-Tyrosine (2g) could enhance cognitive performance, specifically model-based control and temporal discounting, and explore its physiological effects in healthy males.
results_summary: Tyrosine reduced response times without impairing task performance, increased model-based control, and attenuated temporal discounting. It also reduced physiological arousal, with changes in arousal predicting individual changes in temporal discounting.
population_specificity: 28 healthy male participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic performance of O-(2-[(18)F]fluoroethyl)-L-tyrosine (FET) and L-[methyl-(11)C]methionine (MET) in imaging gliomas and brain metastases, as well as evaluating their ability to differentiate tumor tissue from treatment-related changes.
results_summary: The study found strong correlation between FET and MET uptake, similar image contrast, and comparable tumor delineation. Both tracers effectively differentiated viable tumor tissue from benign changes with high sensitivity (91%) and specificity (100%).
population_specificity: 42 patients with pretreated gliomas (29) or brain metastases (13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary restriction of tyrosine and phenylalanine could mitigate nitisinone-induced tyrosinemia in AKU patients and mice.
results_summary: Tyrosine/phenylalanine dietary restriction significantly reduced elevated tyrosine levels in nitisinone-treated AKU mice, while phenylalanine restriction alone was ineffective. In AKU patients, protein restriction alone or combined with tyrosine/phenylalanine-free amino acid supplementation significantly reduced circulating tyrosine levels.
population_specificity: Alkaptonuria (AKU) patients and nitisinone-treated AKU mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified for humans; in mice, phenylalanine supplementation doses varied in drinking water.
study_duration: 3 days for mice; observational study duration for humans not specified.
interactions: Nitisinone treatment was noted to elevate tyrosine levels, leading to potential keratopathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L-Tyrosine (TYR) enhances creativity in convergent- and divergent-thinking tasks by influencing cognitive control.
results_summary: The study found no evidence that TYR improves divergent thinking ("brainstorming"), but it did enhance convergent ("deep") thinking, suggesting it may support control-demanding creative operations.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether genetic differences (C957T polymorphism in the DRD2 gene) influence individual responses to L-Tyrosine supplementation in cognitive tasks involving response inhibition and working memory.
results_summary: The study found that T/T homozygotes (associated with lower striatal dopamine levels) showed greater cognitive benefits from L-Tyrosine compared to C/C homozygotes, suggesting genetic predisposition modulates its effectiveness as a cognitive enhancer.
population_specificity: Individuals with varying C957T genotypes (T/T, C/C) in the DRD2 gene.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document the first case of anaphylaxis caused by supplemental lactase enzyme and assess its allergenic potential.
results_summary: The study reported a severe anaphylactic reaction in a patient after ingesting a lactase enzyme tablet, confirmed by skin prick testing. The reaction was attributed to IgE-mediated allergy to synthetic lactase enzyme.
population_specificity: A 38-year-old Caucasian female with self-diagnosed lactose intolerance and suspected lactase allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether localized supplementation of L-Tyrosine and BH(4) could improve reflex- and pharmacologically induced vasoconstriction in aged human skin.
results_summary: L-Tyrosine supplementation resolved age-related decreases in cutaneous vasoconstriction during whole-body cooling and tyramine infusion, showing comparable efficacy to BH(4). However, combining L-Tyrosine with BH(4) did not further enhance vasoconstriction.
population_specificity: 10 young and 10 older subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lactase enzyme supplementation could reduce excessive crying in infants with colic.
results_summary: The study found that infants receiving lactase enzyme showed significant improvement in crying duration (86.5%) compared to the placebo group (59.6%), with statistical significance (p<0.05).
population_specificity: Infants aged 0-6 months with colic (excessive crying ≥3 hours/day, ≥3 days/week for ≥3 weeks).
effective_dosage: Five drops of lactase enzyme (Colibid) before each feed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of tilactase (a lactase enzyme) and Lactobacillus reuteri versus placebo on hydrogen breath excretion and gastrointestinal symptoms in lactose-intolerant patients during a lactose breath test.
results_summary: Tilactase and Lactobacillus reuteri significantly improved lactose breath test normalization rates and reduced hydrogen excretion and clinical symptoms compared to placebo, with tilactase being more effective than the probiotic.
population_specificity: Sixty lactose-intolerant patients.
effective_dosage: Tilactase was administered 15 minutes before the lactose breath test; Lactobacillus reuteri was taken twice daily for 10 days.
study_duration: 10 days for Lactobacillus reuteri; single dose for tilactase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prophylactic potential of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei against colistin-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae, focusing on its safety, efficacy, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Lacticaseibacillus paracasei demonstrated inhibitory effects against K. pneumoniae, with cell-free supernatant causing pathogen cell surface damage. In vivo studies in mice showed reduced histopathological and microbiological alterations, and genomic analysis confirmed the absence of antibiotic resistance or virulence genes.
population_specificity: Balb/c mice and in vitro models (CaCo-2 cell lines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei LC86 on osteoporosis and cartilage damage in a zebrafish model, focusing on its modulation of the gut-bone axis.
results_summary: LC86 treatment significantly improved bone and cartilage health, upregulated key bone-related genes, altered metabolic pathways, and positively influenced gut microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (Danio rerio) with Dexamethasone-induced osteoporosis and cartilage injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the probiotic properties and antiadipogenic potential of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei TISTR 2593 for obesity prevention.
results_summary: L. paracasei TISTR 2593 demonstrated safety, desirable probiotic properties, cholesterol reduction, and antiadipogenic activity, reducing lipid accumulation by ~50% in adipocytes and modulating key adipogenesis-related transcription factors.
population_specificity: In vitro (3T3-L1 adipocytes) and genomic analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of orally administered Lacticaseibacillus paracasei on vaginal well-being and microbiome modulation in healthy women without bacterial vaginosis.
results_summary: The probiotic group showed significant improvement in self-assessed gut and vaginal health, but no significant changes were observed in the vaginal bacterial community, and colonization of the probiotic strains was not confirmed.
population_specificity: Healthy women aged 19-50 without preexisting health conditions (n=26 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism by which Lacticaseibacillus paracasei E6 improves vinorelbine-induced immunosuppression in zebrafish.
results_summary: L. paracasei E6 colonized the zebrafish intestine and significantly alleviated immunosuppression by increasing macrophage, neutrophil, and T-lymphocyte counts, as well as promoting IL-12 and IFN-γ expressions. The effects were attributed to SCFA metabolites (acetic acid and propionic acid) produced by L. paracasei E6.
population_specificity: Zebrafish with vinorelbine-induced immunosuppression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei strain Shirota (LcS) on reducing aflatoxin biomarker levels and explore individual factors influencing aflatoxin exposure in healthy Malaysian adults.
results_summary: The study found that LcS significantly reduced urinary AFM1 levels by 23% compared to placebo and maintained lower serum AFB1-lysine adduct levels. Ethnicity, knowledge level, and dietary intake were identified as factors influencing aflatoxin exposure.
population_specificity: Healthy Malaysian adults (aged 20-60) of Chinese, Malay, or Indian ethnicities with elevated aflatoxin biomarkers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lacticaseibacillus paracasei K56 supplementation could reduce perceived stress, anxiety, and improve sleep quality among master's and doctoral students.
results_summary: The study found that Lacticaseibacillus paracasei K56 significantly reduced stress and anxiety symptoms, improved sleep quality, and increased serotonin levels compared to placebo. It also modulated gut microbiota composition and increased beneficial metabolites like butyric acid.
population_specificity: Healthy master's and doctoral students facing graduation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lacticaseibacillus paracasei strain Shirota (LcS) on hard or lumpy stools in a generally healthy U.S. adult population with intermittent constipation symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that daily consumption of LcS significantly reduced the proportion of participants with hard or lumpy stools, improved stool consistency, and enhanced quality of life. The intervention was well tolerated with no serious adverse events.
population_specificity: Generally healthy U.S. adults (41 females, 9 males) with a history of hard or lumpy stools in ≥25% of bowel movements.
effective_dosage: 80 mL fermented milk containing 8.0 × 10^9 CFU LcS/mL daily for 28 days.
study_duration: 28 days (intervention) followed by a 14-day postintervention period.

study_goal: The abstract does not specify a particular study goal regarding Low-Level Laser Therapy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Low-Level Laser Therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current prevention and treatment strategies for breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL), including the potential role of low-level laser therapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that low-level laser therapy appears promising in lymphedema management, though no specific efficacy data or comparative outcomes are provided.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with or at risk for lymphedema.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) compared to other conservative treatments for managing carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The evidence for LLLT's effectiveness was inconclusive, with no clear demonstration of significant benefits for CTS management. The study noted that findings were based on low-quality primary studies with high risk of bias and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Individuals with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of physical stimulation methods, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for managing hyposalivation caused by systemic conditions.
results_summary: LLLT showed increased salivation in most cases, except for two studies involving individuals with Sjögren's syndrome (SS), where it was ineffective.
population_specificity: Individuals with hyposalivation due to post-chemotherapy, medication use, postmenopausal women, hemodialysis patients, smokers, diabetics, and Sjögren's syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) combined with physiotherapy improves pain, muscle power, and lactate levels in children with spastic diplegia compared to physiotherapy alone.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain (measured by VAS), muscle power (measured by MVIC), and blood lactate levels in the group receiving LLLT plus physiotherapy compared to the group receiving only physiotherapy after one month.
population_specificity: Forty children with spastic diplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether non-surgical adjunctive interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), could accelerate orthodontic tooth movement and reduce treatment duration.
results_summary: LLLT showed a statistically significant reduction in alignment time during early treatment stages and fewer required appointments, but the clinical significance was questionable. No significant differences were found in other outcomes like pain perception or root resorption.
population_specificity: Children and adults receiving orthodontic treatment with fixed or removable appliances, excluding those with craniofacial syndromes or deformities.
study_duration: Varied by study, with follow-up periods spanning early alignment to space closure stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) in treating temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: Both LLLT and TENS improved pain scores and mouth opening, with no statistically significant difference between the groups. However, LLLT showed significant improvement in lateral excursion movements compared to TENS.
population_specificity: 20 patients diagnosed with temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
effective_dosage: LLLT at 660 nm, 6 J/point, two sessions/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) on pain intensity and disability in adults with plantar fasciitis compared to control conditions, other interventions, and adjunct therapies.
results_summary: PBMT alone or combined with exercise improved short-term pain intensity and was superior to extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) for pain relief. However, PBMT did not consistently outperform other interventions for disability and showed no added benefit as an adjunct therapy.
population_specificity: Adults with plantar fasciitis (1089 participants across 19 RCTs).
study_duration: Short-term, medium-term, and long-term follow-ups (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) after lower molar extraction.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved OHRQoL, with the LLLT group showing lower OHIP-14 scores compared to the control group at 7 and 30 days post-extraction. The combined aPDT + LLLT group had the lowest scores, indicating the strongest improvement.
population_specificity: 40 patients (mean age 41.25, 62.5% women) requiring lower molar extraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze and compare existing clinical trials on Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for oral mucositis in pediatric patients undergoing chemotherapy, identifying shortcomings to guide future research.
results_summary: The review found that LLLT showed faster healing, reduced pain, and decreased analgesic use compared to placebo, but noted inconsistencies in laser parameters, PBM protocols, and a lack of clinical trials.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of electrophysical agents, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, in improving pain, functional status, and mood in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: The study found low to moderate quality evidence that Low-Level Laser Therapy is among the most effective electrophysical agents for improving at least one outcome in fibromyalgia, though specific efficacy details for laser therapy alone were not highlighted.
population_specificity: Patients with fibromyalgia (3045 participants across 54 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of occlusal splints (OSs) with other interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for managing orofacial myalgia and myofascial pain.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to determine whether OS therapy, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, offers an advantage over other interventions or no treatment for orofacial pain. All included studies had a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: 589 patients diagnosed with orofacial muscle pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and pulsed electromagnetic field therapy (PEMFT) on pain and physical function in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: LLLT significantly improved pain and physical function in participants with knee osteoarthritis, though PEMFT was more effective in reducing pain at rest and improving functional scores. The improvements reached clinically meaningful levels.
population_specificity: Participants with grade 2-3 knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence classification).
effective_dosage: Six sessions of 15 minutes each over 3 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on orthodontic tooth movement during maxillary molar distalization over a 12-week period.
results_summary: LLLT significantly increased tooth movement compared to the contralateral and control groups (p < 0.001), with laser-treated molars moving 1.22 times more in 12 weeks. However, the effect was not considered clinically significant despite statistical significance.
population_specificity: Twenty patients undergoing orthodontic treatment for maxillary molar distalization.
effective_dosage: Laser therapy applied for 10 seconds per point at 16 different points on the first and second molars on specified days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on reducing side effects, particularly pain, after the surgical removal of impacted third molars and to establish an optimal irradiation protocol.
results_summary: The study found that one specific LLLT protocol (30-second irradiation at 0.3 W with slow scanning technique) significantly reduced self-reported pain and annoyance compared to the placebo side. Other tested protocols did not show statistically significant differences.
population_specificity: 96 subjects requiring simultaneous surgical removal of all four impacted third molars.
effective_dosage: 30-second irradiation at 0.3 W (energy density not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and electromagnetic therapy (EMT) in reducing trigeminal neuralgia pain and improving muscle action potential amplitude in diabetic patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly outperformed EMT in reducing pain intensity (measured by VAS) and increasing compound muscle action potential amplitude in temporalis and masseter muscles. All groups improved, but the laser group showed the most substantial benefits.
population_specificity: 120 diabetic patients with trigeminal neuralgia (both sexes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy applied to the LI4 point using a laser acupuncture pen could reduce pain perception and dental anxiety in children during local anesthetic administration.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in anxiety and pain perception in children who received low-level laser therapy compared to the control group during local anesthetic administration. The results suggest that laser acupuncture can be an effective intervention for alleviating dental anxiety and pain in pediatric patients.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-12 years requiring local anesthetic administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence supporting the use of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) to improve miniscrew stability in orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: Two RCTs reported increased miniscrew stability with LLLT, while one found no difference. The overall evidence was deemed insufficient to conclusively support or refute LLLT's effectiveness for this purpose.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment with miniscrews.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and laser-activated irrigation (LAI) in controlling post-endodontic pain.
results_summary: LLLT was superior to LAI and the control group (ML) in reducing pain after 24 hours. By 48 hours, both LLLT and LAI were equally effective and significantly better than the control, but no differences remained at 72 hours.
population_specificity: 180 patients undergoing single-visit root canal treatment for symptomatic apical periodontitis.
study_duration: Pain assessed at 24, 48, and 72 hours post-treatment.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on donor site healing after vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue (VIP-CT) flap compared to platelet-rich fibrin (PRF).
results_summary: LLLT-treated sites showed reduced palatal mucosal thickness after 1 week but returned to baseline by 12 weeks, with better contour (less hypertrophic tissue) and faster relief of pain and burning sensation compared to PRF. Both treatments improved post-surgical complications like ecchymosis, tissue necrosis, swelling, and infection by 4 weeks.
population_specificity: Patients requiring VIP-CT flap surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with other conservative interventions on time to return to sport (TRTS) and reinjury outcomes in athletes with acute hamstrings injuries.
results_summary: The study found no evidence supporting the superiority of LLLT in reducing TRTS or reinjury risk compared to other interventions. The certainty of evidence was very low, and LLLT did not demonstrate clinically meaningful benefits.
population_specificity: Athletes (mostly men aged 14-49 years) with acute hamstrings injuries from various sports.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) using 808 nm and 660 nm wavelengths on muscle strength and functional outcomes in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The 808 nm group showed greater improvement in knee extensor strength compared to the 660 nm and sham control groups, while the 660 nm group improved in the 30-s sit-to-stand test. All groups exhibited functional improvements, but no significant differences were found in other performance tests.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis (47 participants).
effective_dosage: 300 mW, 15 minutes per session, three days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness and safety of conservative interventions, including Low-Level Laser Therapy, for pain, disability, and range of motion in adults with cervical radiculopathy.
results_summary: The study found very-low certainty evidence supporting Low-Level Laser Therapy for pain and disability in the immediate to short-term, and for improvements in cervical range of motion in the immediate term. The evidence was inconclusive for multimodal interventions.
population_specificity: Adults with cervical radiculopathy (CR) diagnosed through clinical examination and/or diagnostic tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of LLLT combined with exercise therapy (ET) on pain, range of motion (ROM), muscle strength, and function in knee osteoarthritis (KOA) immediately after therapy and its sustainability at follow-up (4-32 weeks).
results_summary: The study found that LLLT plus ET significantly reduced pain in KOA patients immediately after therapy but showed no significant improvement in ROM, muscle strength, or function compared to placebo. The effects were sustained at follow-up (4-32 weeks).
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (820 participants across 14 RCTs).
effective_dosage: 4-8J per point, wavelength 640-905nm, 10-16 sessions at 2 sessions/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain for patients with plantar fasciitis compared to control treatments.
results_summary: LLLT showed a statistically significant reduction in pain (MD -2.09, CI: -2.28, -1.90) in the short term, indicating effectiveness. However, its efficacy in medium and long-term pain relief was not demonstrated, unlike extracorporeal shock wave therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with plantar fasciitis (15,401 total participants across 236 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the mechanisms of action, dose-response curves, and clinical outcomes of red low-level laser therapy for postoperative pain management.
results_summary: The literature review found that red low-level laser therapy is safe and effective for postoperative pain relief, promotes healing, and reduces the need for prescription analgesics. Seven randomized controlled trials supported these findings.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing various surgical procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to open flap debridement improves clinical outcomes in stage III periodontitis.
results_summary: Both treatments improved periodontal health, but LLLT showed significant additional benefits in reducing gingival inflammation, probing depth, postoperative pain, and dentinal hypersensitivity compared to debridement alone.
population_specificity: 10 patients with stage III periodontitis (70 sites of periodontal pockets).
effective_dosage: Low-level diode laser (wavelength 808 nm), exact dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) with botulinum toxin type-A (BTX-A) and anterior repositioning appliance (ARA) in treating temporomandibular joint disc displacement with reduction (DDwR).
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain and improved disc position and joint space index compared to the control group (ARA), with faster recovery times. The effects were statistically significant and comparable to BTX-A.
population_specificity: 27 patients with symptomatic temporomandibular joint disc displacement with reduction (DDwR), divided into three groups of 9 each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on symptom improvement in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: The study found that real LLLT significantly improved total symptom scores compared to sham laser, with a 34.12% improvement versus 5.02% for sham. No significant improvements were observed after sham laser treatment.
population_specificity: Fourteen adult patients with CRS (12 male, mean age 40 years).
effective_dosage: Ga-Al-As laser of 830 nm, continuous mode, 30 mW power output, 1 J energy dose, applied on six points per sinus for 33 seconds each.
study_duration: Five sessions of sham laser followed by five sessions of real laser after 2 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of PBMT and PEMF for treating androgenetic alopecia (AGA).
results_summary: The study found that a combination of PBMT and PEMF was effective and safe for treating AGA, with improvements in hair density observed over the 24-week trial period.
population_specificity: 80 subjects with androgenetic alopecia.
effective_dosage: PBMT: 15-minute therapy weekly for the first 12 weeks, then every other week for the next 8 weeks; PEMF: 10-minute therapy with the same frequency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) alone, Stabilisation Splint Therapy (SST) alone, and their combination in treating chronic closed lock (CCL) from temporomandibular joint disc displacement without reduction (DDwoR).
results_summary: The study found that combined SST and LLLT provided the best and quickest improvement in maximum mouth opening (MMO), pain reduction (VAS), and muscle/joint palpation scores compared to either therapy alone. LLLT alone showed significant improvement over SST alone in some measures but was less effective than the combined treatment.
population_specificity: 42 patients diagnosed with chronic closed lock (CCL) from temporomandibular joint disc displacement without reduction (DDwoR).
study_duration: Evaluations were conducted at baseline, 1, 2, 4 weeks, 3 and 6 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) and Extracorporeal Shockwave Therapy (ESWT) on pain and function in patients with plantar fasciitis.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant reductions in pain, disability, and activity limitation, with 95% of participants achieving clinically important differences in pain, while ESWT showed no significant changes. LLLT was found superior to ESWT for short-term management of plantar fasciitis.
population_specificity: Patients with plantar fasciitis (n = 47, with 20 in the LLLT group).
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 3 weeks.

study_goal: To explore emerging second-line treatment options like low-level laser therapy for female pattern hair loss in PCOS patients.
results_summary: The abstract mentions limited data supporting the efficacy of low-level laser therapy for hair growth in PCOS patients, with no specific results reported.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) experiencing female pattern hair loss (FPHL).

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of laser therapy for managing orofacial pain (OFP) and identify optimal treatment parameters for pain reduction, functional improvement, and quality of life.
