results_summary: Laser therapy was more effective than placebo in improving pain, maximal mouth opening, jaw protrusion, and tenderness. It outperformed occlusal splints for pain relief but was not superior to TENS or medication.
population_specificity: Adults with orofacial pain, including temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) of myogenous, arthrogenous, and mixed types.
effective_dosage: Diode or GaAlAs laser, wavelength 400-800 or 800-1500 nm, dosage <25 J/cm².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) could reduce pain caused by dental anesthetic injections.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant but clinically insignificant reduction in pain during dental injections with PBMT (mean VAS score 21.2 vs. 27.9 in the control group). The authors concluded that PBMT prior to injections offers no clinical advantage for pain reduction.
population_specificity: 30 dental students (60 bilateral canine teeth).
effective_dosage: 940 nm diode laser (specific power/dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in treating herpes labialis through a systematic review and meta-analysis of clinical trials.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy significantly reduced healing time by 1.37 days (p < 0.0001) but showed no significant effect on crust formation time (p = 0.150). The therapy was deemed effective, but most included studies had a high risk of bias, necessitating further standardized research.
population_specificity: 928 patients with herpes labialis across 7 randomized clinical trials and 1 clinical trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether therapeutic taping, including Kinesio taping with low-level laser therapy, was effective in improving pain, grip strength, and function in patients with De Quervain's Disease (DQD).
results_summary: The study found that therapeutic taping, including Kinesio taping with low-level laser therapy, did not significantly improve pain, grip strength, or function in DQD patients compared to other treatments like ultrasound and exercise. The meta-analysis showed no statistically significant benefits (p > 0.05).
population_specificity: Patients with De Quervain's Disease (DQD), totaling 241 participants across seven clinical-controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain and disability in patients with lower extremity tendinopathy and plantar fasciitis.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain and disability both immediately after therapy and at follow-up periods of 4-12 weeks, particularly when used at recommended doses. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity tendinopathy or plantar fasciitis.
effective_dosage: Recommended doses based on World Association for Laser Therapy guidelines (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Therapy duration varied, with follow-up assessments at 4-12 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on pain and swelling after flapless computer-guided implant site preparation using a novel surgical guide.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced pain and swelling scores compared to the control group within the first 48 hours and up to day 3 post-surgery, with minimal differences by days 4 and 7. Females reported higher pain scores than males, but swelling did not differ significantly between genders.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with a history of bilateral extractions in the lower molar area at least 6 months prior.
effective_dosage: Diode laser with a wavelength of 980 nm and 100 mW energy for 1 minute.
study_duration: Single session immediately after implant insertion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), piezocision, and their combination in accelerating orthodontic tooth movement (OTM).
results_summary: LLLT, piezocision, and their combination significantly accelerated canine retraction, with LLLT + piezocision showing the strongest effect (1.93 mm improvement) and LLLT alone the weakest (0.51 mm improvement). The effects were statistically significant (p < 0.05) and showed consistent acceleration over 9 weeks.
population_specificity: 32 patients (64 quadrants) undergoing bilateral first premolar extraction and canine retraction.
effective_dosage: LLLT (940 nm, 8 J, 0.5 W, 16 s, 12 sites per session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT/PBM) in reducing arm circumference/volume and improving shoulder mobility and pain severity in women with metastatic breast cancer-related lymphedema.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced arm circumference/volume at four weeks and maintained this effect in long-term follow-up, but no statistically significant improvements were observed in shoulder mobility or pain severity compared to placebo groups.
population_specificity: Women with metastatic breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
study_duration: Short-term follow-up at 0-, 1-, 2-, and 3-month intervals; long-term follow-up duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-level laser therapy could attenuate joint capsule fibrosis and the progression of arthrogenic contracture during remobilization by modulating inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy was found to attenuate joint capsule fibrosis and the progression of arthrogenic contracture by suppressing remobilization-induced inflammatory reactions, similar to steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
population_specificity: Individuals with joint immobilization-induced contracture undergoing remobilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the controversy surrounding vaginal laser therapy and distinguish between ablative and non-ablative vaginal lasers for gynecologic and pelvic conditions.
results_summary: The abstract highlights ongoing controversy and the need for further research but does not provide conclusive efficacy results. It emphasizes the importance of understanding laser types before clinical integration.
population_specificity: Patients with gynecologic and pelvic conditions (e.g., vaginal atrophy, dyspareunia, urinary incontinence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the applications of lasers, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), in dermatological settings, focusing on vascular, infectious, and hyperpigmented cutaneous lesions, as well as cosmetic purposes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights LLLT and laser resurfacing as marketable lines for cosmetic purposes but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes for LLLT. The review frames laser applications broadly without detailed results on LLLT's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dermatological applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-frequency and low-frequency Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) on canine retraction rates and IL-1β levels in gingival crevicular fluid.
results_summary: LLLT significantly increased canine retraction rates and IL-1β levels compared to control sides, with no significant difference between high-frequency and low-frequency application groups.
population_specificity: Twenty patients undergoing canine retraction.
effective_dosage: Group A: LLLT on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and every 2 weeks thereafter; Group B: LLLT every 3 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of prolonged low-level laser therapy combined with exercise on pain and disability in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that low-level laser therapy, both initially isolated and later combined with exercise, significantly reduced pain, disability, and medication intake over a 6-month period compared to placebo. The Laser group showed sustained improvements at all follow-up points, while the Placebo group had minimal or no improvement.
population_specificity: Forty-three participants with knee osteoarthritis (mean age 63.02 years).
effective_dosage: Three times a week for 3 weeks (laser/placebo), then three times a week for 8 weeks (laser + exercise).
study_duration: 11 weeks (3 weeks laser/placebo + 8 weeks laser + exercise), with a 6-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) for pain control in patients with temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders.
results_summary: The study found that photobiomodulation is an effective adjunct treatment for TMJ disorders, demonstrating low risk of bias, safety, low cost, and no side effects. However, due to study heterogeneity, a meta-analysis could not be performed.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in reducing pain within the first 48 hours after orthognathic surgery compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced pain scores within the first 48 hours post-surgery compared to placebo, though the evidence quality was rated as very low. The effect size was moderate (SMD: -0.690).
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthognathic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of macrophages, particularly M2 subtypes, in diabetic wound healing under photobiomodulation (PBM) and advance macrophage-based therapies for diabetic foot ulcers.
results_summary: PBM, alone or combined with other agents (e.g., stem cells), moderated inflammatory responses and accelerated wound healing in preclinical diabetic wound models, though few studies detailed the functions of polarized macrophages and M2 subtypes under PBM.
population_specificity: Preclinical and clinical diabetic wound models (type 1 and type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare two Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) protocols for pain control, swelling, and trismus after lower third molar surgeries.
results_summary: Both LLLT protocols showed similar effectiveness for pain, swelling, and trismus, with no significant differences between them. However, Protocol A (multiple applications) reduced analgesic use at 24 hours post-surgery compared to Protocol B (single application).
population_specificity: Patients with symmetrically impacted mandibular third molars (21 patients, 42 teeth).
effective_dosage: Intraoral (660nm, 5 J/cm², 10 s, 20 mW, 4 points) followed by extraoral (789 nm, 30 J/cm², 20 s, 60 mW, 8 points).
study_duration: Immediate post-surgery (T1), 24 hours (T2), and 48 hours (T3), with follow-up at 7 days (T4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in preventing and reducing the severity of oral mucositis (OM) in cancer patients undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT).
results_summary: The study found promising outcomes for LLLT in reducing the incidence and severity of OM, though larger, tightly controlled clinical trials are needed for conclusive evidence.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing HSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) at red (660 nm) and infrared (810 nm) wavelengths in preventing and treating radiotherapy-induced oral mucositis (OM) in head and neck cancer patients.
results_summary: LLLT was effective in reducing OM lesions, with the combination of 660 nm and 810 nm wavelengths yielding lower OM scores compared to either wavelength alone. The therapy improved outcomes in patients undergoing radiotherapy with or without chemotherapy.
population_specificity: 80 subjects diagnosed with head and neck cancer (HNC) undergoing radiotherapy.
effective_dosage: Group I: 660 nm LLLT; Group II: 810 nm LLLT; Group III: combined 660 nm and 810 nm LLLT (specific power/dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in preventing tooth sensitivity after tooth whitening.
results_summary: The review found that LLLT showed promise in preventing tooth sensitivity post-whitening, but evidence was limited, and more high-quality clinical trials are needed for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing tooth sensitivity after tooth whitening.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of photobiomodulation (PBM) and antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) as adjunct treatments for oral mucositis in oncology patients undergoing chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy.
results_summary: Both PBM and aPDT reduced the degree of mucositis and pain scores, with aPDT showing earlier clinical improvement. aPDT also demonstrated a greater reduction in Candida yeasts compared to the control and PBM groups.
population_specificity: 30 oncology patients (over 18 years old) undergoing chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy with stable oral mucosa lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) on wound healing, pain, and discomfort at free gingival graft (FGG) donor sites.
results_summary: PBM significantly improved wound healing at FGG donor sites one and two weeks post-surgery but showed no significant difference in pain, discomfort, or color match scores compared to the control group. Bleeding was higher in the test group on the day of surgery.
population_specificity: Sixteen patients requiring bilateral free gingival grafts.
effective_dosage: LLLT GaAlAs 940 nm, 5 J/cm² (specific frequency not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments occurred on days 7, 14, 28, and 60 post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) could reduce fatigue in individuals with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in fatigue levels, as measured by the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS), between the two photobiomodulation administration methods (under the tongue or over the radial artery). Photobiomodulation with the tested parameters had no effect on fatigue in the studied population.
population_specificity: Individuals with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis recruited from the UNINOVE Integrated Health Clinic.
effective_dosage: 808 nm, 36 J for 360 s (single session details provided, but frequency not specified).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (abstract mentions a pilot study but does not specify intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically analyze the effects of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) on implant stability and postoperative recovery.
results_summary: PBMT increased implant stability at 10 days and reduced marginal bone loss at 6 months but showed no significant improvements at other time points. It was effective only in reducing facial swelling, with no notable impact on postoperative pain, bone mineral density, or peri-implant clinical parameters.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing dental implant procedures.
study_duration: Varied follow-up periods (10 days to 12 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine newer treatment modalities, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for managing immune-mediated diseases with oral presentations.
results_summary: The abstract states that LLLT has shown positive results in immune-mediated diseases, though its use in Photodynamic Therapy (PDT) is contentious. No specific adverse effects or limitations are mentioned.
population_specificity: Patients with immune-mediated diseases exhibiting oral signs and symptoms (e.g., oral lichen planus, pemphigus vulgaris).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of low-level laser acupuncture on postoperative pain, morphine consumption, and related side effects in older patients after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: Low-level laser acupuncture significantly reduced postoperative pain intensity and morphine consumption within 72 hours after surgery, with notable improvements in pain-related interference in daily life and fewer morphine-related side effects like nausea and vomiting.
population_specificity: Older patients with knee osteoarthritis who underwent total knee arthroplasty (N = 82).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of photobiomodulation using low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on spinal cord injury (SCI) in experimental models.
results_summary: LLLT showed potential as an auxiliary therapy for SCI, demonstrating neuroprotective effects, functional recovery, increased nerve connections, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines. However, the study highlighted a lack of standardization in dosimetric parameters.
population_specificity: Experimental models of spinal cord injury.
effective_dosage: Power varied from 25 to 200 mW, total energy from 0.3 to 450 J, and application time from 8 to 3000 s.
study_duration: Treatment ranged continuously from 5 to 21 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) in patients with neurotmesis of the inferior alveolar nerve following mandibular fractures.
results_summary: PBMT significantly improved light touch sensations, sharp touch sensations, and two-point discrimination in patients with neurotmesis, with statistically significant trends observed. The PBMT group also showed higher mean scores in the OHIP-14 test 3 months post-treatment, though no significant differences were found in EPT and thermal discrimination tests.
population_specificity: Patients with neurotmesis of the inferior alveolar nerve following mandibular angle and body fractures, with symptoms persisting for at least 6 months (26 participants: 3 female, 23 male).
effective_dosage: Low-level GaAlAs diode laser (810 nm wavelength, 200 mW power, 12-14 J/cm² energy density).
study_duration: Intervention administered over at least 10 sessions (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) is more effective than electrical stimulation (E.S.) in promoting facial nerve regeneration and improving clinical outcomes in patients with Bell's palsy.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly improved nerve conduction velocity, nerve action potential amplitude, and latency compared to E.S. and the control group, along with better outcomes on the Sunnybrook facial grading system (SBGS).
population_specificity: 45 patients with Bell's palsy, divided into three equal groups.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in patients with discogenic lumbar radiculopathy and its correlation with pain intensity, functional disability, and lumbar range of motion.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant improvement in outcomes for the group receiving LLLT combined with conventional physical therapy compared to the control group receiving only conventional physical therapy. LLLT was concluded to be an efficient adjunct therapy for discogenic lumbar radiculopathy.
population_specificity: 110 participants with discogenic lumbar radiculopathy, mean age 38 ± 7.4 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effectiveness of intranasal LLLT compared to acupuncture in treating allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: Intranasal LLLT was noninferior to acupuncture in improving total nasal symptom scores (TNSS) and showed similar improvements in quality of life and nasal endoscopy indices. No significant differences were found between the two treatments for other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 80 patients with allergic rhinitis.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes per session, 3 times a week for 4 weeks.
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment with effects observed 4 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immediate effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) applied to classical acupoints versus trigger points for patients with cervical myofascial pain syndrome (MPS).
results_summary: Immediate pain relief was observed in the trigger point therapy (TriT) group, which also showed improved cervical range of motion (ROM) in ipsilateral bending. The acupoint therapy (AcuT) group did not show similar improvements in ROM.
population_specificity: 100 participants with cervical myofascial pain syndrome.
effective_dosage: 810-nm low-level laser therapy (specific dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Immediate effects assessed post-therapy (duration of intervention not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunct to conventional root canal treatment on postoperative pain and periapical healing.
results_summary: LLLT combined with conventional root canal treatment showed better healing of periapical lesions at 3 and 9 months compared to conventional treatment alone. Postoperative pain was lower in the LLLT group, though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 40 subjects with periapical lesions.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 9 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and radiographic success rates of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LPBM) and formocresol pulpotomy in human primary molars at 9 months post-intervention.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in clinical success rates between formocresol pulpotomy (97.05%) and LPBM pulpotomy (94.1%), suggesting LPBM could be a viable nonpharmaceutical alternative.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-7 years with at least two primary molars indicated for pulpotomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether different Nd:YAG laser applications (including LLLT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planning improve periodontal therapy outcomes in smokers with periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that Nd:YAG laser applications (including LLLT) significantly improved probing depth and clinical attachment level reductions compared to SRP alone, particularly in moderately deep and deep pockets, though no significant differences were observed in gingival index, plaque index, bleeding on probing, or MMP-8 levels.
population_specificity: Eighty systemically healthy smokers with periodontitis.
study_duration: Outcomes measured at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months after treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and corticosteroid injection in patients with moderate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The study compared LLLT (15 sessions over five times a week) with corticosteroid injections (40 mg triamcinolone acetate) in moderate CTS patients, but the abstract does not specify the comparative outcomes or efficacy results.
population_specificity: 87 patients (143 wrists) with moderate carpal tunnel syndrome.
effective_dosage: LLLT applied at a fluence of 6 j/cm², five times a week for 15 sessions.
study_duration: 15 sessions (frequency not specified beyond five times a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate effects of different doses of photobiomodulation (Low-Level Laser Therapy) on maximum lip pressure.
results_summary: The study found that only the 7 J dose of Low-Level Laser Therapy significantly increased maximum lip pressure, while lower doses (1 J and 4 J) did not produce significant changes. The effect was observed immediately after application.
population_specificity: 23 women and 17 men, aged 18–33 years (average 23.18 years).
effective_dosage: 1 J (G1), 4 J (G4), and 7 J (G7) applied at six points on the orbicularis oris muscle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and radiographic effectiveness of MTA partial pulpotomy with low-power or high-power diode laser irradiation in primary molars.
results_summary: MTA and low-power laser (LLLT-MTA) groups showed 100% clinical success, while high-power laser (DL-MTA) had slightly lower success rates (95.2% at 6-9 months, 87.5% at 18 months). Radiographic success rates were highest for LLLT-MTA (100% at 6 months, 88.2% at 18 months), but no significant differences were found among groups.
population_specificity: Children with mandibular second primary molars requiring vital pulp therapy.
effective_dosage: Low-power laser (660 nm, 200 mW), high-power laser (810 nm, 1 W).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 6, 9, and 18 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy in controlling postoperative pain following lower third molar extractions.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy showed statistically significant reductions in postoperative pain on both the second and seventh days after surgery, with moderate effect sizes. The results were consistent across the included randomized clinical trials.
population_specificity: Patients aged 16-44 years undergoing lower third molar extractions.
study_duration: Pain was assessed on the second and seventh days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on chemotherapy-induced oral mucositis in pediatric leukemia patients.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced oral mucositis grade on days 3, 5, 6, and 7 and consistently lowered pain scores compared to the control group from the first day onward. Both standard care and LLLT improved mucositis grade and pain.
population_specificity: Pediatric leukemia patients aged 3-18 undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: GaAlAs diode laser (830 nm, 150 mW, 4.5 J/cm²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy on tooth movement during Class II intermaxillary elastics treatment.
results_summary: Low-level laser therapy (970 nm) did not reduce the time needed to achieve Class I occlusion but significantly increased the total distance of tooth movement and the rate of movement compared to the placebo group. Pain levels were not significantly different between the laser and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Forty-two patients with Class II malocclusion.
effective_dosage: 970 nm diode laser (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain and disability in patients with plantar fasciitis (PF).
results_summary: LLLT improved pain in the short term compared to placebo and showed benefits when combined with conventional rehabilitation, but its superiority disappeared when compared to extracorporeal shock wave therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with plantar fasciitis (817 participants across 14 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the photobiomodulated bioenergetic effects of mitochondria in osteoblasts derived from human dental pulp stem cells.
results_summary: Three out of four reviewed studies confirmed positive bioenergetic effects of photobiomodulation on mitochondria of osteoblasts from human pulp cells, though reporting on bioenergetics was found to be inadequate.
population_specificity: Human dental pulp stem cells differentiated into osteoblasts.
effective_dosage: Laser and LED types (InGaAlP, InGaN, InGaAsP) with wavelengths of 630 to 940 nm; specific dose and time parameters not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) with topical aloe vera in managing oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: LLLT showed significant reductions in pain (VAS by 44.1%), site score (by 24.6%), and activity score (by 50%) during the treatment period, outperforming aloe vera. Both treatments were equally effective during the follow-up period.
population_specificity: 60 patients with oral lichen planus (OLP).
study_duration: 2 months of active treatment, with follow-up for 9 months.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in accelerating the early treatment of skeletal anterior open bite (AOB) and assessing associated skeletal and dentoalveolar changes.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT significantly reduced the time needed to correct AOB compared to the control group (7.07 vs. 9.42 months) and enhanced upper first molar intrusion (1.21mm vs. 0.82mm). Both LLLT and fixed posterior bite block were effective in treating AOB, with most changes being dentoalveolar.
population_specificity: 42 patients aged 8-10 years with skeletal anterior open bite.
effective_dosage: 808-nm wavelength Ga-Al-As semiconductor laser, 4-joules/point, 16 seconds/point, applied at first visit, then on days 3, 7, and 14 of the first month, followed by every 15 days until treatment completion.
study_duration: Until the end of the active phase (mean time of 7.07 months for the LLLT group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the evidence on the effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain, edema, and trismus following orthognathic surgery.
results_summary: LLLT showed potential as an auxiliary tool for reducing pain and trismus post-surgery, but its effect on edema was inconclusive due to lack of standardized measurement. Two studies reported significant improvements in mouth opening with LLLT, while others had mixed results.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent orthognathic surgery (total of 190 participants across five studies).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 14 to 60 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically analyze existing systematic reviews and provide updated evidence on the effectiveness and safety of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: The study found conflicting results on LLLT's effectiveness, with some benefits compared to compression therapies, placebo laser, or no treatment, but no significant improvement over other active interventions. The evidence quality was low to very low, and no treatment-related adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of ILIB-Modified Low-Level Laser Therapy on periodontal parameters and glycemic control in patients with periodontitis and type II diabetes.
results_summary: The study compared conventional periodontal therapy alone versus combined with ILIB-M laser applications, measuring periodontal and glycemic outcomes over 4 months. Results indicated improvements in periodontal parameters and glycemic control in the test group, though specific statistical significance was not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis and type II diabetes (n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy combined with stretching exercises improves pain and functionality in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that laser therapy combined with stretching exercises improved pain during rest, daily activities, stiffness, muscle shortening, and range of motion in knee osteoarthritis patients.
population_specificity: 215 knee osteoarthritis patients (430 knees treated), average age 63.52 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether topical anesthesia combined with Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) reduces injection pain and affects anesthesia efficacy and duration in children undergoing pulpotomy treatment.
results_summary: The study found that LLLT combined with topical anesthesia reduced injection pain compared to topical anesthesia alone, with higher "no pain" rates and lower "severe pain" rates. However, it did not significantly affect anesthesia efficacy or duration.
population_specificity: 60 children aged 6-9 years undergoing pulpotomy treatment.
effective_dosage: 810 nm diode laser, continuous mode, 0.3W, 20 s, 69 J/cm².
study_duration: Single session during local anesthesia administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Photobio-modulation (PBM) therapy is effective for managing Oral Lichen Planus (OLP), its potential as a replacement for conventional therapies, and the need for standardized protocols.
results_summary: PBM showed positive effects in managing OLP symptoms, particularly in cases unresponsive to conventional therapies or where high corticosteroid doses posed risks. However, there was significant heterogeneity in laser parameters, and effective doses ranged from 2 to 3 J/cm².
population_specificity: Patients with Oral Lichen Planus (OLP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) as an adjunctive treatment for accelerating orthodontic tooth movement (OTM) in patients undergoing canine retraction after premolar extraction.
results_summary: Frequent micro-osteoperforations (MOP) combined with LLLT were found to be efficacious and safe for accelerating OTM in the first month after application, but the effect did not persist beyond that period. The evidence supporting this was of low quality.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing extraction of maxillary first premolars followed by canine retraction in any orthodontic setting.

study_goal: To compare the efficacy of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) versus occlusive splint therapy (OST) on TMJ opening index (TOI) and sEMG of masticatory muscles in females with unilateral myogenous TMD.
results_summary: LLLT showed significant reductions in TOI, VAS, and sEMG, outperforming OST and controls. Post-hoc comparisons confirmed LLLT's superiority in improving pain and jaw function.
population_specificity: 112 female subjects aged 21-30 with unilateral myogenous TMD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of photobiomodulation (PBM), specifically Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), on cytokine levels during orthodontic tooth movement (OTM).
results_summary: LLLT increased levels of IL-1β, IL-8, OPN, and PGE2 but not TNF-α1 or TGF-β1, with conflicting results for IL6, RANKL, and OPG. The evidence for increased IL-1β levels was statistically significant but of low certainty due to protocol variations and limited studies in the meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic tooth movement (OTM).
effective_dosage: Wavelengths varied from 618 to 980 nm; light emission patterns differed (specific dosage details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel low-level laser device designed for vaginal use in treating chronic pelvic pain in women.
results_summary: The study found that the low-level laser therapy significantly reduced pelvic pain and pain during activities like exercise, urination, bowel movements, and intercourse in two-thirds of the women who completed the therapy.
population_specificity: Women with chronic pelvic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of different LLLT dosages (10, 8, and 4 J/cm²) compared to placebo in treating diabetic foot ulcers (DFU).
results_summary: The abstract suggests LLLT is effective for DFU treatment but does not provide specific outcome data; the study design implies a comparison of dosage efficacy.
population_specificity: 80 volunteers with diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of laser auricular acupuncture, psychological counseling, and their combination in reducing nicotine dependence among smokers.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction in nicotine dependence and physical effects related to smoking across all intervention groups, with the greatest reduction observed in the group receiving combined laser acupuncture and psychological counseling. Symptoms like irritability, tiredness, and craving also decreased significantly in the combined therapy group.
population_specificity: 150 smokers meeting eligibility criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) improves muscular performance and soreness recovery in physically active athletes.
results_summary: LLLT applied before exercise significantly improved lower-limb muscle strength at various follow-up intervals (24-hour to 8-week) and reduced soreness markers like serum creatine kinase, interleukin-6, and oxidative stress indicators. The study noted a trend toward improved contract repetition and VO₂ metrics but emphasized the need for further robust trials.
population_specificity: Physically active athletes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short- and long-term effectiveness and sustainable benefits of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) for treating burning mouth syndrome.
results_summary: LLLT demonstrated favorable outcomes in both short- and long-term assessments for burning mouth syndrome, showing consistent efficacy in pain reduction.
population_specificity: Patients with burning mouth syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of laser acupuncture and intravascular laser irradiation of blood (ILIB) for managing anxiety in pediatric dentistry.
results_summary: The study found that both ILIB and laser acupuncture were feasible alternatives for managing dental anxiety in children, with the laser acupuncture group receiving 40 seconds of treatment and the ILIB group receiving 10 minutes of treatment.
population_specificity: 84 children recruited at a university dental clinic.
effective_dosage: Laser acupuncture: 40 seconds over points VG20, PC6, and the Oppression Point; ILIB: 10 minutes.
study_duration: Single session (40 seconds for laser acupuncture, 10 minutes for ILIB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of non-steroidal drugs alone versus laser therapy at different doses in treating acute low back pain.
results_summary: Laser therapy combined with drug therapy was more effective than drug therapy alone in relieving pain and disability in acute low back pain patients, though evidence supporting this conclusion was deemed inadequate. Significant differences in pain scores and disability were observed between groups over four weeks.
population_specificity: 65 patients with acute low back pain, randomized into four groups.
effective_dosage: Laser therapy at 3 J/cm² (group 2) and 6 J/cm² (group 3), frequency not specified.

study_goal: To review and critically appraise research on photobiomodulation (PBM) for promoting diabetic foot and lower leg ulcer healing in humans.
results_summary: PBM improved wound healing rates compared to standard care alone, with effective wavelengths of 630-660 nm and 850-890 nm and radiant exposure of 3 J/cm². However, study weaknesses like small sample sizes and inconsistent protocols were noted.
population_specificity: Humans with diabetic foot and lower leg ulcers.
effective_dosage: Radiant exposure levels of 3 J/cm² (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immediate and 1-month efficacy of near-infrared laser therapy in treating dentinal hypersensitivity compared to placebo or no treatment.
results_summary: Near-infrared laser therapy significantly reduced immediate and 1-month follow-up VAS scores compared to placebo/no treatment, with high statistical heterogeneity across studies.
population_specificity: Patients over 18 years with dentinal hypersensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of laser applications in orthopedics, focusing on biophysical mechanisms and clinical potential, particularly for Low-Level Laser Therapy.
results_summary: The study highlights limited clinical applications of lasers in orthopedics outside of Low-Level Laser Therapy, emphasizing the need for further experimental and theoretical research to enhance safety and efficacy. It suggests that modern light delivery devices and robotic guidance could revolutionize clinical laser use.
population_specificity: Not specified (general orthopedic applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on postoperative pain after single-visit root canal retreatment in mandibular molars.
results_summary: LLLT significantly reduced postoperative pain intensity at the 4-hour interval compared to the sham group, though the most intense pain in both groups was reported at 24 and 48 hours post-treatment.
population_specificity: Healthy patients requiring root canal retreatment on symptomatic first or second mandibular molars with specific pain and PAI index criteria.
effective_dosage: 980-nm diode laser set at 6.89 W/cm² (exact frequency not specified).
study_duration: Single-visit intervention with follow-up pain assessments at 4, 24, and 48 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of photobiomodulation (PBM) on brain functions during aging and discuss its mechanisms relevant to the aging brain.
results_summary: PBM showed neuroprotective and neuromodulatory effects in animal models, with human studies indicating improved metabolic, hemodynamic, electrophysiological, and cognitive functions such as attention, memory, and mood in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults and animal models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and discuss the effectiveness of Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) in optimizing the regeneration of peripheral axons and improving motor function.
results_summary: The study found evidence that LLLT enhances peripheral axon regeneration and motor function, particularly in animal models, but noted the need for further clinical evidence and mechanistic elucidation.
population_specificity: Animal models (specific species not mentioned) and implied relevance to human clinical treatment of nerve injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of dexamethasone with other treatments, including Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT), for oral lichen planus (OLP).
results_summary: The study found that dexamethasone was more advantageous than LLLT in treating OLP, though the evidence was limited due to small sample sizes and heterogeneity. Comparable effects were observed between dexamethasone and other treatments in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients with oral lichen planus (OLP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether photobiomodulation (PMB) could influence body temperature and muscle fatigue during a muscle fatigue protocol.
results_summary: The laser group showed a less pronounced decrease in muscle strength and lower muscle fatigue rates compared to the placebo group. The control group exhibited the highest average temperature, with PMB demonstrating a positive effect on muscle fatigue attenuation and thermoregulation.
population_specificity: 14 volunteers (crossover study)
study_duration: Not specified (assessed at 0, 5, 10, and 15 minutes post-test)

study_goal: To assess the efficacy and safety of oral low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing oral mucositis in children and young people undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: LLLT may reduce the severity of oral mucositis and oral pain, but further randomized controlled trials are needed to confirm efficacy. Safety data showed minor and infrequent adverse reactions, though study quality varied.
population_specificity: Children and young people with cancer undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: To evaluate whether Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT) improves the success rate of inferior alveolar nerve blocks (IANB) in patients with symptomatic irreversible pulpitis (SIP).
results_summary: The study found that adding LLLT to IANB significantly increased anesthesia success rates from 34% to 57%, though it was insufficient for complete pulpal anesthesia. The difference between groups was statistically significant (p = .032).
population_specificity: 88 patients diagnosed with symptomatic irreversible pulpitis in mandibular molar teeth.

study_goal: The abstract does not address Low-Level Laser Therapy; it focuses on the potential of dental stem cells for hard tissue regeneration, particularly bone, and their applications in research and clinical translation.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Low-Level Laser Therapy; it summarizes the potential of dental stem cells for osteogenesis, angiogenesis, and tissue regeneration, highlighting their research and clinical applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract discusses dental stem cells in general, not a specific human or animal population).
